metadata.title: True Epidemic Growth Construction Through Harmonic Analysis

body_text.text: Abstract. In this paper, we have proposed a two-phase procedure (combining discrete graphs and wavelets) for constructing true epidemic growth. In the first phase, a graphtheory-based approach was developed to update partial data available and in the second phase, we used this partial data to generate plausible complete data through wavelets. We have provided two numerical examples. This procedure is novel and implementable and adaptable to machine learning modeling framework.
Key words: partial to complete data, convergence of graphs, wavelets. 27

In general, it is not easy to build a true epidemic growth curve in a timely fashion for 29 any newly emerging epidemic, and the chances of building a true growth picture worsen with 30 poor disease reporting. As we know, preparedness for the epidemic spread is a primary public 31 health concern for any health department. Epidemic reporting of a disease is a fundamental 32 event in understanding two key parameters in epidemiology, namely, epidemic diffusion within then after 21 days, these individuals will (unknowingly) spread the virus to others. There are 42 other viruses whose incubation period is short but they are contagious during this period, 43 for example, influenza. Even for epidemics with established symptoms, reporting could be 44 nowhere close to complete. The impact of reporting on epidemic surveillance can then be 45 theoretically measured (Rao, 2012) . 46 Wavelet theory was developed fairly recently (about 35-40 years ago), but applications 47 of wave functions fitted to epidemic data were seen more than 60 years ago (for example, 48 Soper (1929), Bartlett (1956) and Bartlett 1957) . The observations by Bartlett (1957) on 49 population size and the fraction of measles infecting people over various time points provided 50 a new basis for using stochastic models for understanding retrospectively the seasonality of 51 epidemics. This study by Bartlett (1957) and other studies (for example, see the summary 52 in the book by Anderson and May (1991) ) consider wave-like fitting of a time series data of 53 epidemics. Wavelet theory has revolutionized the study of image compression, the study of signal pro-128 cessing, and the study of partial differential equations. It will be a powerful new tool in the 129 study of epidemiology, particularly in the analysis of epidemic growth curves. This study will develop methodologies of constructing complete data from partial data 132 using wavelets.

First, we propose to build a true wave of an epidemic (through harmonic analysis set-up and 134 assumptions) that is otherwise unknown directly. Then, by assuming that a fraction of this 135 constructed wave was reported out of a true wave, we will determine how an observed wave 136 appears. These fractions are variables, so we will have several patterns of waves representing 137 one true epidemic wave. We will draw conclusions as to which one of these representations 138 is an ideal candidate for building a true epidemic. There will be some noise in our modeling 139 of the epidemic curve so we will use noise reduction techniques before finalizing a pattern.

This work is innovative because wavelets have never before been used to build on partial 163 epidemic information. The wavelets thus built will be retrospectively updated. This will be 164 a new technology to improve reported data and to re-construct epidemic dynamics. These 165 methods, we anticipate, will be innovative for several other medical science applications. We have argued how various combinations of partial data can be used for discrete con- paper, we demonstrated a method of improving partial data to be close to data that could 415 be complete. How we plan to update our data reported in an interval and bring it closer to 416 the actual number of disease cases is described in this paper. Table 1 and in the Table 4 .

This exploration will assist in better visualization of any emerging epidemic spread in a 418 more realistic sense. We also believe that our methods could provide additional tools for 419 those epidemic modelers who frequently use modeling tools such as ODE and PDE, to begin 420 with. We are not only looking for academic development through this project but, also 421 a clear non-trivial body of techniques for applications of harmonic analysis that has never 422 been seen before in terms of developing epidemic analysis. We plan to come up with some 423 interesting insights on how to construct wavelets for medical applications. The bottom line 424 is that we will be able to help public health planners for better management and courses of 425 action during emerging epidemics. The kind of analysis we present here to fill missing pieces 426 of epidemic reporting information can be applied to other areas, for example, constructing 427 total rhythm of a heartbeat from partial information, etc. 428 We have identified a gap in the methods of understanding true epidemic growth and spread introduced to the literature through this study. A solution through wavelets is also not trivial 435 because there is no ready-made set of wavelets available which will offer a timely road-map.
So we have introduced a novel strategy. Hence we argue that our approach will help us to come closer to our aims of understanding epidemics in a more accurate and timely fashion.
As a bi-product, we can develop techniques for data scientists to analyze disease surveillance.
